text: - [Instructor] Welcome to this video
where we'll guide you through the process
of enabling Amazon GuardDuty,

a powerful machine learning
based threat detection service
in both a standalone account
and a multi-account environment.
Log into the AWS Management console

and navigate to the
Amazon GuardDuty service.

Click on the get started button
to begin the setup process.

Review the GuardDuty
service permission details
as well as the protection plans.

Please note that enabling
GuardDuty for the first time

will automatically enable all
GuardDuty protection plans,

except runtime monitoring and
malware protection for S3,
both of which you can enable
by using the GuardDuty console or APIs
Click on Enable GuardDuty.

GuardDuty will now start
analyzing your AWS environment
for potential threats.

You can review the findings
and manage the service
through the GuardDuty dashboard.

To get started with
enabling Amazon GuardDuty
in a multi-account environment,
there are a few prerequisites.

Firstly, you must be in
the same organization
as all accounts that you want to manage.
Next, you also need to have access

to the AWS Organization's
Management account

in order to delegate an
administrator for GuardDuty
within your organization.

Please note you must also
have the required permissions
to delegate a GuardDuty administrator.

This enables GuardDuty
as a trusted service
in AWS organizations.

It also enables the Delegated
Administrator account
to enable and manage GuardDuty
for other accounts in the organization
in the current region.
For more information

on how to delegate a
GuardDuty administrator,
please refer to permissions required

to designate a delegated
GuardDuty administrator account
on the Amazon GuardDuty user guide.
Log into the AWS Management console

and navigate to the AWS
Organization's console.
Copy the account number of the account
that you would like to delegate

as the Amazon GuardDuty
delegated administrator account.
The AWS security reference architecture

suggests using the
security tooling account

as the Amazon GuardDuty
delegated administrator.

This is because the
security tooling account

is dedicated to operating
security services,
monitoring AWS accounts

and automating security
alerting and response,

ensuring least privilege
with controlled access

to manage access to the
security guardrails,
monitoring, and response.

Now, navigate to the
Amazon GuardDuty console
and click on settings.

Enter the delegated administrator
account ID into the field.
Click Delegate.
You have now successfully delegated

a GuardDuty administrator
for your AWS organization.

Log into the delegated
administrator account
and open the Amazon GuardDuty console.
Click on accounts.

The accounts table
displays all the accounts
within your AWS organization.

Choose the accounts that
you want to add as members

by selecting the box
next to the account ID.

Then from the action
menu, select Add Member.

You have successfully
enabled Amazon GuardDuty
for your AWS organization.

To continue adding
member accounts in future
as your organization grows,

you can add accounts manually
from the accounts page,

or you can choose to automate
adding new accounts as members
by turning on the auto enable feature.
When you click on Edit,

you can manage your
auto enable preferences.
For example, I can choose to auto enable
Amazon GuardDuty for all accounts

or for new accounts within
my AWS organization.
Beyond the foundational data sources
ingested and analyzed by the service,
Amazon GuardDuty also provides options
for workload protection,

such as Amazon S3 runtime
monitoring, EKS, malware,
RDS, and Lambda Protection Plans.
Note that explicit permissions

must be given to your
delegated administrator

to enable malware protection
across your AWS organization.

You can centrally auto
enable protection plans
for your organization
via your delegated administrator account,
or enable them manually.
Note that as best practice,

AWS suggests that you
auto enable GuardDuty

for all accounts within
your AWS organization,
as well as select all protection plans
to be enabled for all accounts.

This ensures that you can
continuously detect threats,

including data exfiltration
from your Amazon S3 buckets
instance, or container compromise
and detection of malware in your instance,

or container workloads
and Amazon S3 buckets.
Manually enabling Amazon GuardDuty
for multiple accounts or organizations

across multiple regions
or through the console
can be complex.

You can also use tools
to automate the process

such as the CLI, Cloud
Formation, or Terraform.

Amazon GuardDuty and all
its protection plans,
except for malware protection,
comes with a 30 day free trial
for every account in each region

to help you evaluate the service
and estimate future cost.
Malware protection for free trial

is only available for Amazon
GuardDuty initiated scanning
for Amazon EBS data volumes.

There is no free trial for
malware protection for Amazon S3.
Today, you have learned how to enable
Amazon GuardDuty for a standalone account
and for your AWS organization.
To learn more,

please refer to the Amazon
GuardDuty user guide

for an in-depth understanding
of Amazon GuardDuty
and its protection plans.
If you have questions,

please don't hesitate to
contact your AWS account team
or ask a question on AWS repost.
Thank you for watching.
